title-group.article-title: An Electromagnetic Micro Power Generator for Low-Frequency Environmental Vibrations

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2006 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: This paper presents an electromagnetic (EM) vibration-to-electrical power generator which can efficiently scavenge energy from low-frequency external vibrations. The reported generator increases the conversion efficiency by up-converting the low-frequency environmental vibrations to a much higher frequency. Power is generated by electromagnetic induction between a magnet and coils placed on top of resonating cantilever beams. The calculated maximum power from a single cantilever is 2.5Î¼W in vacuum for vibration frequencies 1Hz to 1kHz.

ref.mixed-citation: P. B. Koenaman et.al., "Feasibility of micro power supplies for MEMS," JMEMS, Vol. 6, No. 4, pp. 355-362, Dec. 1997.
M. Mizuno et. al, "Investigation of a resonance microgenerator," J. of Micromech. Microeng., Vol 13, pp. 209-216, 2003.
S. Meninger et. al., "Vibration-to-electric energy conversion," IEEE Trans, on VLSI Systems, Vol. 9, No. 1, pp. 64-76, 2001.
C.B. Williams et. al., "Analysis of a micro-electric generator for microsystems," Sens, and Actuators A Vol. 52, pp. 8-11, 1996.
H. Kulah and K. Najafi, "An Electromagnetic Micro Power Generator for Low-Frequency Environmental Vibrations," Digest of MEMS 2004, pp. 237-240, 2003
S. G. Kelly, "Fundamentals of Mechanical Vibrations," Chapter 3, McGraw-Hill, 1997.
H. Hosaka et. al., "Evaluation of energy dissipation mechanism in vibrational microactuators," MEMS'94, pp. 193-198, 1994
